articles.headline: S.E.C. Chief Offers Rules to Govern Fast Trading
articles.snippet: The proposed changes outlined by Mary Jo White would touch virtually every corner of the market.
articles.abstract: The proposed changes outlined by Mary Jo White would touch virtually every corner of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | The stock market has transformed in the last decade into a place dominated by high-speed traders zapping orders to many exchanges, while regulators have been slow to react.

articles.headline: Bergdahl Is Said to Have History of Leaving Post
articles.snippet: A classified report on the Army’s investigation into Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s disappearance in June 2009 says he had left assigned areas before and then returned, according to people briefed on it.
articles.abstract: A classified report on the Army’s investigation into Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s disappearance in June 2009 says he had left assigned areas before and then returned, according to people briefed on it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A classified military report detailing the Army’s investigation into the disappearance of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in June 2009 says that he had wandered away from assigned areas before — both at a training range in California and at his remote outpost in Afghanistan — and then returned, according to people briefed on it.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Fund Manager Sets Goats Grazing in Blighted Detroit
articles.snippet: The financier Mark Spitznagel brought 20 billy goats to graze on overgrown grass among abandoned homes and general detritus.
articles.abstract: The financier Mark Spitznagel brought 20 billy goats to graze on overgrown grass among abandoned homes and general detritus.
articles.lead_paragraph: To most of the world, the solution to debt-ridden Detroit is money. But for one hedge fund manager, it’s goats.

articles.headline: The Islands Treasured by Offshore Tax Avoiders
articles.snippet: United States companies told the I.R.S. that they earned $129 billion in 2010 in Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands, but their real earnings are more complex.
articles.abstract: United States companies told the I.R.S. that they earned $129 billion in 2010 in Bermuda, the Cayman Islands and the British Virgin Islands, but their real earnings are more complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you know that United States companies earned $129 billion in 2010 in three small groups of islands?

articles.headline: Chester Nez, 93, Dies; Navajo Words Washed From Mouth Helped Win War
articles.snippet: Mr. Nez helped fashion from his Navajo language a military code so impervious that it helped the United States secure victory in the Pacific in the summer of 1945.
articles.abstract: Mr. Nez helped fashion from his Navajo language a military code so impervious that it helped the United States secure victory in the Pacific in the summer of 1945.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the end of his life, Chester Nez recalled the first message he sent over the radio while serving at Guadalcanal: “Enemy machine gun nest on your right. Destroy.”

articles.headline: Some See G.M. Report as Powerful Ammunition for Change
articles.snippet: Mary T. Barra, the head of General Motors, called an internal investigation released on Thursday an occasion for the automaker to clean house.
articles.abstract: Mary T. Barra, the head of General Motors, called an internal investigation released on Thursday an occasion for the automaker to clean house.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief for regulatory affairs is gone. So is a senior lawyer and two midlevel engineers. Two safety executives were also let go. The list is long — at least 20 in all — of those dismissed or disciplined by General Motors for their role in the company’s failure to correct a deadly safety defect in millions of its small cars.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Bond Rally Is Squeezing the Trading at Big Banks
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s top banks bet on a bear market for Treasuries this year. But with bonds rising, some firms are worried about their bottom lines.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s top banks bet on a bear market for Treasuries this year. But with bonds rising, some firms are worried about their bottom lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s biggest firms this year made an extraordinary wager that they probably now regret.

articles.headline: For a Decade, G.M. Response to a Fatal Flaw Was to Shrug
articles.snippet: The Valukas report details a decade-long tale of denial, incompetence and tragic nonchalance at General Motors.
articles.abstract: The Valukas report details a decade-long tale of denial, incompetence and tragic nonchalance at General Motors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just six months ago, a group of senior General Motors executives gathered to review a series of PowerPoint slides concerning a question that had been smoldering inside G.M. for a decade: Should the company recall hundreds of thousands of small cars because of a dangerous defect?
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: War’s Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing
articles.snippet: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces, prompting concern that brain injuries and stress have not been properly treated. Susan Ullman’s husband, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, committed suicide last summer.
articles.abstract: Suicides have increased among the military’s Special Operations forces, prompting concern that brain injuries and stress have not been properly treated. Susan Ullman’s husband, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, committed suicide last summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: After his fourth combat tour, to Afghanistan in 2011, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, a proud member of the Army Special Forces, came home alienated and angry. Once a rock-solid sergeant and devoted husband, he became sullen, took to drinking, got in trouble with his commanders and started beating his wife.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: 217,000 Jobs Added, Nudging Payrolls to Levels Before the Crisis
articles.snippet: Employers hired 217,000 workers in May and the unemployment rate remained flat at 6.3 percent.
articles.abstract: Employers hired 217,000 workers in May and the unemployment rate remained flat at 6.3 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a series of peaks and valleys that confounded optimists and pessimists alike this year, the American economy seems to have settled into a healthy, if not spectacular, pace of job creation.

articles.headline: Buying a Guaranteed Retirement Income, for Some Peace of Mind
articles.snippet: Many people at or nearing retirement age are purchasing deferred-income annuities that will provide them with an extra monthly income check.
articles.abstract: Many people at or nearing retirement age are purchasing deferred-income annuities that will provide them with an extra monthly income check.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many workers long for the sense of security that only an old-fashioned pension can provide. The big insurers are well aware of this, and that’s why many of them are offering new ways for investors to buy and build a pension on their own.
